channel.title: Posts on Jincheng Li
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Jincheng Li

item.title: Update
item.description: I realized that if I’m going to keep every article in the blog well thought-out and organized, it’d take me several full days to complete each one. The result is that my last article was over a year ago, and I may never finish another one again. I still want to keep this blog alive, so I’m just going to use it as a dumping ground for my finished / unfinished technical writings.

item.title: PostgreSQL Query Optimization
item.description: The other day I saw a tweet about blog posts it would be great to see, and one of them was “inside PostgreSQL: how a join works internally, what makes it fast”. Coincidentally, I’m taking a course on database system implementation, and I thought this would be a great way to study for my midterm! Of course, by the time I’ve finished this post, the midterm is long gone, but it was still a great incentive for me to start writing :)

item.title: Why This Blog
item.description: This is probably my last year as a student, when I still have a lot of freedom allocating my time. In the hopes of putting my spare time to better use than playing Witcher 3 and Hearthstone, I decided to start writing some technical articles. This would be a good opportunity for me to do some research into things I never dedicate enough time to understand, and hopefully benefit whoever chances upon this little blog :)

item.title: What Happens When You Press the Power Button on Your Linux Computer
item.description: I wanted to start a series of posts on how the Linux operating system works, inspired by linux-insides, but instead of covering the entire operating system which is way too much work for my lazy ass, I’ll focus on several aspects of the OS and try to do a good job explaining them – I’m hoping to make this comprehensible for someone who’s seen some assembly and C, but isn’t necessarily familiar with the internals of an OS.
